'There are nine kinds of causes that give rise to heedlessness. If one indulges in and creates much of that heedlessness, it will destroy foolish ordinary beings in the world. When their bodies perish and their lives end, they will fall into evil destinies - the hells, hungry ghosts, or animals.
Because of the causes of birth, one undergoes great suffering, is bound by birth and death, and cannot attain the bliss of nirvana and peace. One cannot obtain benefit.
What are the nine causes?

First, it is said that one delights in negligence, practices negligence, always practices negligence, does not approach sages, cannot regulate the actions of body, speech, and mind, does not restrain the senses, cannot correct one's own body, speech, and mind, causes one to engage in unwholesome objects, always delights in hearing unwholesome dharmas, and does not delight in the Buddha's true Dharma.
This is the first cause of negligent conduct, which can give rise to negligence.

If one practices negligence, foolish beings engage in unwholesome bodily actions, unwholesome verbal actions, and unwholesome mental actions. Because of unwholesome bodily, verbal, and mental actions, unwholesome karma of body, speech, and mind accumulates.
Foolish people, deceived by negligence, upon the destruction of the body and the end of life, fall into evil paths and are born in the realms of hell, hungry ghosts, or animals.
If one abandons carelessness, one is a good man and always abandons carelessness.
If one seeks goodness, one should abandon carelessness.
This is the first cause that can give rise to carelessness.
